title: Has there ever been a good dictator at any point in history? If so, which ones were good? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is a proverb from West Africa: "Until lions have their historians, tales of the hunt shall always glorify the hunter." When we are constantly reminded of the horrors inflicted in Cambodia, the Soviet Union, North Korea, Uganda, or Germany, it can be a daunting task to find dictatorial rulers that challenge the norm. I wrote an answer to a similar question about Joseph Pilsudski. Has there ever been a "good dictatorship"? Is humankind capable of doing this? But this time, I will focus on another dictator, one who remains largely unknown in the western world.  Thomas Sankara (1949-1987) was dictator of the west African nation of Burkina Faso from 1983 to 1987. His regime was authoritarian to say the least, but it was one of brief and peculiar form. Despite after thirty years, many African scholars and political philosophers look to Sankara's vision of a united Africa. Even today, he is considered a hero by many Burkinabe as well as Africans. When I first heard of Sankara, which was just a few years ago, I was really shocked. This guy was really a piece of work, and yet I never heard of him until then. As a former resident of Africa, I admit to being embarrassed over my own ignorance. Even my father had met him briefly during Sankara's visit to Addis Ababa. Thomas “Tom Sank” Sankara was an officer in the Burkinabe military when the country was known as Upper Volta. His father served in the French army during WW2 and was held as a POW by the Germans. As an officer cadet, Thomas Sankara was influenced by marxist writings during his military education in Madagascar. He gained a heroic reputation during the 1974 border war with Mali and was also a popular guitar player. He was strongly influenced by Che Guevara and fashioned his rock star image in a similar manner. Even as president, Sankara continue to wear his signature military fatigues and red beret. As such, he is commonly known as "Africa's Che".  Courtesy of Guardian.com. Sankara arrives in Addis Ababa. I suspect my father is somewhere in this crowd In 1983, with broad support from fellow officers and citizens, Sankara was installed as president after Jean-Baptiste Ouedraogo was overthrown. Some support was provided by Qadaffi, who at the time was not on friendly terms with the French (Chadian-Libyan conflict). In the brief period he ruled, Sankara initiated a number of policies which has given him a favorable reputation throughout the continent. I'll write them all in bullet point. * On the first anniversary of his coup, he got rid of the name "Upper Volta". In accordance with his anti-imperialist stance, Sankara removed the name as it was given by the French colonists. He renamed the country as Burkina Faso, which means "Land of Upright (or Incorruptible) People" in the local Mossi and Djula languages. He even personally composed the national anthem which remains used today. * Another early change he implemented was the replacement of the government's luxurious Mercedes cars, such as this 1980s model...  with this...  The Renault 5, at the time the cheapest available car in Burkina Faso. Under Sankara's presidency, it was the official vehicle for all government employees, including himself. Honestly, can you think of a single 'democratic' African president willing to drive in this? In addition, officials, including ministers, were not permitted to hire private chauffeurs or use 1st class airline tickets. Sankara stated that before his presidency, the country's ministers took more luxury trips to the US and Europe than to the countryside of Burkina Faso. * He changed traditional power structures among tribal chieftains. No longer were they allowed to extract tribute from peasants or forced labor. Local farmers now owned the land they worked on. This allowed Sankara to further implement a policy of self-sufficiency. By redistributing feudal landholdings and instituting large-scale irrigation and fertilization projects, Burkina Faso was producing enough of its own food and no longer dependant on foreign aid. In 1986, Burkina Faso was producing 3800 kg of wheat per hectare, more than double of the average 1700 produced by other countries in the Sahel region. "The science of the multinationals does not offer them these means, preferring to invest in cosmetics laboratories and plastic surgery to satisfy the whims of a few women or men whose smart appearance is threatened by too many calories in their overly rich meals, the regularity of which would make you—or rather us from the Sahel—dizzy" * With the aid of Cuban doctors, he launched a national vaccination program to eradicate polio, meningitis and measles. In one week, 2.5 million Burkinabe were vaccinated, a feat that earned Sankara the congratulations of the World Health Organization. Sankara was also the first African leader to publicly acknowledge the threat of AIDS to Africa's development, a revolutionary act considering that AIDS denialism is still thriving on the continent. * Promoted women's rights and their political participation. He was among the first African leaders to appoint female cabinet members and his government consisted of 20% women, more than most African nations. Even military service was open to women. (Some say that, like Qadaffi, Sankara had female bodyguards that rode motorcycles. But I haven't found any evidence indicating this is more than a rumor) He also banned female genital mutilation, forced marriages, child marriages, and polygamy. Right to divorce and widow's right to inherit were introduced. Contraception was promoted and if a girl became pregnant, she was allowed to remain in school. He argued it was discrimination if a girl should remain at home because of her pregnancy, while the boy who made her pregnant may continue his education. By placing the pregnant girls in the same class, boys would be reminded of their irresponsibility on a daily basis and be less encouraged to "fool around". In addition, he introduced "women's day" every year, in which men would perform the chores traditionally assigned to women, such as buying food at market or cooking. Men were to experience first-hand the conditions endured by their wives and daughters. "The revolution and women’s liberation go together. We do not talk of women’s emancipation as an act of charity or because of a surge of human compassion. It is a basic necessity for the triumph of the revolution. Women hold up the other half of the sky"  Excerpt from Sankara's speech to the Organization of African Unity in Addis Ababa * In a number of international forums, such as the Organization of African Unity, Sankara advocated for African nations to oppose the economic exploitation by western corporations and repudiate the foreign debt. He argued that the poor and exploited do not have the obligation to pay the rich and exploiting. The purchase of weapons from western nations to be used against fellow Africans was also an obstacle to development. And last but not least, he pushed for a common African trade organization (similar to the European Union) which would allow African nations to trade and exchange labor. These ideals have also been promoted by other pan-African leaders. * Privately, Sankara was a man of very few possessions. He lowered his monthly salary to $450, owned one Renault car, four cheap motorcycles, three guitars, a fridge and a broken freezer. His simple home had no air conditioning, and he would not install any until every Burkinabe had one in their home. By refusing to wear a business suit, Sankara denounced the opulent lifestyle of politicians. Wherever he went, he either dressed in his iconic military uniform or traditional African shirts. * His portrait did not hang in any public places, unlike many African nations where they have laws requiring a portrait of incumbent presidents in public areas. * Launched a nation-wide reforestation campaign to prevent the gradual encroaching Sahara. 10 million trees were planted, and new owners or tenants of new housing units were required in their housing/rent contract to plant and care for a minimum number of trees. Women and youth built tens of thousands of improved stoves to reduce the consumption of firewood. An old tradition of cultivating trees in towns and villages was revived, and each family was given the means to plant one hundred trees per year. The cutting and sale of firewood was strictly regulated. In summary, Sankara's policies were radical, massive, and groundbreaking, even by modern standards. All of these campaigns were conducted by the minimal resources the people had at their disposal, and their accomplishments surpassed most African nations at the time. And each of these projects were performed for one reason only: to improve the nation in all aspects, whether they be educational, political, social, economical, environmental, or spiritual. And not once did Sankara claim praise for these accomplishments. As far as dictators go, I can't think of a single one which surpasses his modesty.  Now that I'm done with listing his positive contributions to Burkina Faso, I'm going to list the negative consequences of his leadership. "Our revolution will be the most authoritarian thing there is; it will be an act through which the people impose their will by all available means, including arms if necessary" Sankara's regime did not go uncriticized by humanitarian organizations, including Amnesty International and Freedom House. Shortly after the revolution, seven officials from the previous administration were summarily trialed and executed. As far as dictators go, Sankara would no doubt be among the top "least violent" authoritarian leaders of modern history. Capital punishment was banned and none of his political opponents were executed. Even Sankara's predecessor Ouedraogo is alive and well, running a medical clinic to this day. Sankara's standard punishments of dissent were often job dismissal, community service, or public humiliation. Even the OECD admitted that although violence was not uncommon, killings were remarkably few. It is difficult to determine whether many of the crimes committed during this period were in accordance with Sankara's instructions or self-serving members of his regime. Many of his comrades were ideological followers of Joseph Stalin, Mao Zedong, and Enver Hoxha. They were less concerned than Sankara over potential abuses, were intolerant of dissent, and favored coercion. They favored harsher reprisals over Sankara's lenient methods. In 1987, Oxfam recorded the arrest and torture of several trade union leaders. In addition to the regime's negative aspects, there were also mistakes. As popular as he is today, Sankara did implement a number of failed policies. Among his setbacks were his educational programs to combat the country's 90% illiteracy. In 1987, 2,500 teachers went on strike to protest. Instead of negotiating, Sankara had them dismissed and tried to replace them with volunteers, but their lack of teaching experience did not lead to any improvements. Another of his dubious policies was the People's Revolutionary Tribunal, a series of courts he introduced where average citizens could accuse government officials of tax evasion, corruption and "counter-revolutionary" behavior. Although these courts were initially approved by the people for their inclusive process, the trials became increasingly haphazard and sometimes exploited for personal gain. Fortunately, the sentences were lenient and often suspended. Apart from the Tribunals, Sankara also created Revolutionary Defense Committees, inspired by the Cuban Committees for the Defense of the Revolution founded by Fidel Castro in 1960. Similarly, Sankara's CDR was to promote social and political revolution while opposing counter-revolutionary influences. Unfortunately, many abused these committees for personal gain, behaving no better than armed thugs. At the very least, Sankara himself publicly admitted that the Committees had failed in their original intent. In the end, the negative results of the Revolutionary Teachers program, the Tribunals and the Defense Committees would lead to a growing discontent towards Sankara. Though still popular among the poor, disdain had been stimulated among the middle class and tribal chieftains, those who gained the least from his leadership. Not to mention that the Ivory Coast and its patron France were growing concerned over Sankara's pan-African activities.  Sankara seated with Blaise Compaore, a member of the trio behind the 1983 coup which brought Sankara to power On October 15th 1987, Sankara was killed during a coup organized by his closest ally and deputy Blaise Compaore, alongside Zongo and Lengani. Relations between the two had turned sour, and Blaise defended the coup on the grounds that Sankara was deteriorating relations with nations such as the Ivory Coast and France. Some argue that the French were worried that Sankara's revolutionary ideals would spread to other former French colonial holdings, including the Ivory Coast. It's worth noting that Compaore's wife was very close to Felix Houphouet-Boigny, president of the Ivory Coast at the time. Houphouet-Boigny was founder of the term "Françafrique " and opponent to other left-leaning leaders in western Africa such as Ghana's president Kwame Nkrumah, another leader with pan-African views similar to Sankara. When the French magazine JeuneAfrique printed allegations that Houphouet-Boigny was involved in Sankara's assassination, he demanded the French government ban the publications.  The "Communist Officer's Group". Compaore, Lengani and Zongo were the officers who liberated Sankara from prison and installed him as president. Two years after Compaore's coup in 1987, Lengani and Zongo were charged with treason and executed. Compaore would remain in power until 2014 After becoming president, Compaore immediately reversed many of Sankara's policies, and rejoined the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. He took out big loans in order to "repair" the country's economy, yet after 27 years with little improvement, one wonders where all that money really went. Currently, Burkina Faso is one of the poorest nations in Africa and Compaore would remain president for 27 years before being ousted in a coup in 2014. During the coup, the BBC described Compaore as the strongest ally of the French and Americans in western Africa. Coincidentally, Burkina Faso has also become one of the top producers of gold on the continent, actively mined by the following firms. Goldrush Resources (Canadian), Gryphon Materials (Australian), Orbis Gold Limited (Australian), Golden Rim Resources (Australian), Cluff Gold (English), Randgold Resources (English), Channel Resources (Canadian), Etruscan Resources (Canadian), Goldbelt Resources (Canadian), High Rivers Gold Mines Limited (Canadian), Orezone Gold Corporation (Canadian), Riverstone Resources (American), Societe Semafo (Canadian) It's worth pointing out though, that Sankara's legacy can arguably be attributed to the brief period he ruled. Four years is not much of a "dictatorial reign", so there is always the possibility that his passionate committment may have deteriorated over time. There are countless examples of dictators that eventually refuse to back down, regardless of their intentions prior to becoming dictators. A friend of mine once joked, "Thomas Sankara was one of those dictators who was lucky enough to die before he screwed things up." In retrospect, there may be truth to these words, but we will never truly know. But what we do know is that Sankara's policies were reversed immediately by Compoare, thus reducing the benefits they had provided to the country. Even after almost thirty years, many Burkinabens today describe the 83-87 period as a highlight of their modern history.  Now that Compoare has been ousted from government, it remains to be seen how prominent Sankarist ideals will become in the new Burkina Faso. So in conclusion, Sankara was a dictator with traits that made him stand out. He was authoritarian, but not corrupt. He had firm, yet not brutal control. He was radical, but also a visionary. He was honest, but sometimes misguided. He also had a sense of humor and personality, almost always smiling in public and using jokes to point out the absurd situation in post-colonial Africa. An interesting combination of leadership traits. Jazz, rivalry and revolution: Burkina Faso recalls spirit of Sankara https://www.jacobinmag.com/2015/05/thomas-sankara-burkina-faso-assassination/ Thomas Sankara's Speech at the United Nations / Discours de Thomas Sankara aux Nations Unies Why Burkina Faso’s late revolutionary leader Thomas Sankara still inspires young Africans

response.answer_text: Muammar Gaddafi, Libya.  This man is generally condemned by whole world. Libya was, indeed, a dictatorship country, in terms of one man leading it for decades. But not in the way media would have you believe. I had the pleasure of talking to a Libyan while war was going on there. When I asked about war, what they want to achieve, and how is the state of affairs in their country, he looked a bit ashamed and said "I am starting to be ashamed of my people. Stupid".  Here are some facts about life in Libya: Electricity was free. For everyone.Loans were given by government, and they had 0% interest rate by default. Before Gaddafi, 20-30 % of people were literate. More than 80 % are educated now. In Gaddafi "Green Book", sort of like what we know as Constitution, it said "The house is a basic need of both the individual and the family, therefore it should not be owned by others.". Everyone had to have a house, even if it meant that government would have to buy it. Price of petrol was 0.14$Education and medical care was free in Libya. If they didn't have the means, or room to help you, you would be sent out of country and taken care of, while all of the bills would be paid by government. Oh, while you are in treatment in foreign country, you would be transferred 2.300$ every month, free to spend as you like. If you wanted to go to college, but they didn't have it in Libya, you would be sent to appropriate university outside of country, and have tuition paid by the government - while still receiving monthly allowance from your country.Since Libya has huge oil reserves, a small percentage of whole oil trading profit was split between every (yes, every) citizen of Libya, and transferred to their bank account. If you graduated, but didn't have job in your degree, you would be paid average salary for the position by the government until you find a job, or until they find a spot for you. Every mother would receive 5.000$ for every child she gave birth to. Atop of all this, Libya had NO external debt to ANYONE, and it's federal reserves were about 150 billion dollars, mostly overseas - and frozen now. I really believe that this example may be one of best to show that justice doesn't always work. Libyans had more than perfect life, and while we are straggling with economy, job losses, mortgages, tuitions, they had it all for free. Instead of making a statue of this man, and treating him as a saint of sorts, they ravaged their own country, got to him, killed him, and dragged him on the street like he was their dungeon master.  If I knew this before, I would gladly live in Libya. It was probably the best dictatorship people ever lived under. Better than people live in US now, better than people live in Europe now, in all the "first world countries".

What was left of the Republic of China had a “good dictator” named Chiang Ching-kuo, who ruled the rump state as its president from 1978 until his death in 1988, and before that as its premier (from 1972 to 1978).[1]  Chiang Ching-kuo The son of Chiang Kai-shek, the embattled Chinese Nationalist leader who had ruled Taiwan before him, Chiang Junior enjoys a much better reputation among Taiwanese; polls consistently place him as the most popular president in the island’s history. [2]  Left: “Which president loves Taiwan the most?” 32.8% say Chiang Ching-kuo. Right: “Which president made the biggest contributions to Taiwan?” 53.3% say Chiang Ching-kuo. Chiang Junior was a dictator; for most of his presidency, Taiwan was ruled under martial law, Chiang’s party (the KMT) was in total control, and opposition to the government was rarely tolerated. But Chiang Junior also presided over a period of rapid economic growth that helped keep Taiwan on the map even after the Republic of China was kicked out of the United Nations and broke off diplomatic ties with several countries, including the United States, which recognized the People’s Republic of China (PRC) at the beginning of Chiang’s presidency. During Chiang’s rule, Taiwan’s real GDP growth rate frequently exceeded 10%, and it was among the 20 economies with the largest contributions to global economic growth. [3]  Taiwan’s real GDP growth rate frequently exceeded 10% during the 1980s [4] Wages in Taiwan were also on the increase throughout the 1980s and continued to rise until after 1998. [5]  Monthly average income in Taiwan (in NT$), 1980–2016 Perhaps most importantly, Taiwan was the richest region in the Greater China region, with a total GDP exceeding that of every province in mainland China and Hong Kong. By the time of Chiang’s death, Taiwan’s economy was so large that it was nearly half the size of mainland China’s economy — which had also grown tremendously since the previous decade. [6]This gave Taiwan a lot of leverage over its rivals in Beijing, who had to endorse a more accommodating approach towards the regime in Taipei so that Taiwan can contribute to developing the mainland.  GDP of mainland China and Taiwan, 1970–2013. In 1980 (towards the beginning of Chiang’s rule), Taiwan’s GDP was 13.7% the size of mainland China’s. By 1990, two years after Chiang died, that percentage had risen to 43.8%. Obviously, Chiang Junior did not single-handedly grow Taiwan, but he did play a substantial role in building it. As premier, he proposed the so-called “Ten Major Construction Projects,” a series of projects that upgraded the island’s infrastructure and set the foundations for fast growth. [7] These projects included a north-south highway that connected the largest city in northern Taiwan (Taipei) with the largest city in the south (Kaohsiung), the Chiang Kai-shek Int’l Airport in Taipei/Taoyuan (later renamed Taoyuan Int’l Airport), and Taichung Port (now the second-largest port in Taiwan).  Highway No. 1, aka the Jhongshan/Zhongshan Freeway, completed in 1978 Aside from being a good administrator, Chiang Junior was a relatively benevolent ruler in spite of his authoritarian tendencies. In 1985, Chiang announced that he would not be succeeded by a member of his own family, just as he had succeeded his father a decade earlier. [8] The first question is the succession to the presidency. This sort of question only exists in despotic and totalitarian countries. It does not exist in the Republic of China, based on the Constitution. So the next President will be elected in accordance with constitutional procedure by the National Assembly on behalf of the people. Some people may raise the question whether any member of my family would run for the next presidency. My answer is: it can't be and it won't be. (he ended up picking a successor who was quite shit but that’s another story) Following an airline hijacking in 1986 that brought a Taiwanese plane to mainland China (caused by a pilot who had left the mainland for Taiwan during the civil war and wanted to reunite with his family), Chiang agreed to enter contact with the PRC to get the plane back and allowed ROC military veterans to visit their families on the mainland, paving the way for civilian travel across the Taiwan Strait. [9] And in 1987, Chiang ended martial law on Taiwan, formally kickstarting a process of liberalization that culminated in the first direct presidential elections in 1996 and the first peaceful transfer of power from one party to another in 2000.  Chiang Ching-kuo’s executive order ending martial law in the Taiwan Area effective July 15, 1987 (that first peaceful transfer of power gave power to a president who was a demagogue and crook, but again, that’s another story) As someone who does not identify with the current incarnation of the Republic of China, I must say that the ROC was blessed to have had Chiang Ching-kuo as its ruler. His may have been a dictator, but his dictatorship was a net gain for Taiwan. And don’t just take my word for it — the majority of Taiwanese (81% in 2003, 77%/65% in 2007) also agree that Chiang Junior’s pros outweigh his cons. When a poll asked which leader can lead Taiwan out of pain in the aftermath of a natural disaster, more respondents said Chiang Ching-kuo:  Footnotes[1] Chiang Ching-kuo - Wikipedia[2] http://>小蔣辭世30年 過半民眾仍感念政績！歷任總統 蔣經國貢獻最大 - 政治要聞 (https://www.chinatimes.com/newspapers/20180112000497-260118?chdtv)[3] List of countries by GDP growth 1980–2010 - Wikipedia[4] Why Taiwan is the most exciting market in Asia - MoneyWeek[5] 台灣受僱者的收入，68％有個上不去的40K天花板 - The News Lens 關鍵評論網[6] 大陆台湾历年gdp比较_wh2005_新浪博客[7] Ten Major Construction Projects - Wikipedia[8] Chiang: Constitution To Determine His Successor[9] Jamin Chen's answer to What are some underrated turning points in history?

Salvador Allende..  Presidency of Salvador AllendeDuring its first year in office, the Allende Government achieved economic growth, reductions in inflation and unemployment, a redistribution of income, and an increase in consumption. The government also significantly increased salaries and wages, reduced taxes, and introduced free distribution of some items of prime necessity. Groups which had previously been excluded from the state labor insurance scheme (mainly the self-employed and small businessmen) were included for the first time, while pensions were increased for widows, invalids, orphans, and the elderly. The National Milk Plan affected 50% of Chilean children in 1970, providing 3,470,000 with half a litre of milk daily, free of chargeThe land-redistribution that Allende highlighted as one of the central policies of his government had already begun under his predecessor Eduardo Frei Montalva, who had expropriated between one-fifth and one-quarter of all properties liable to takeover.The Allende government's intention was to seize all holdings of more than eighty basic irrigated hectares.Allende also intended to improve the socio-economic welfare of Chile's poorest citizens; a key element was to provide employment, either in the new nationalised enterprises or on public works projects. United States intervention in ChileThe Washington sees their loss of $$$ when Allende nationalized many of U.S corporations there and Chilean nationalization of copper. They immediately cut their aid off and switch it into more support of Allende’s opposition.Federal government of the United States ( the Richard Nixon’s Administration ) wants to shut the spread of Communism during Cold War and as they think Allende is a Marxist past then.Henry Kissinger's 40 Committee and the CIA planned to impede Allende's investiture as President of Chile with covert efforts known as "Track I" and "Track II"; Track I sought to prevent Allende from assuming power via so-called "parliamentary trickery", while under the Track II initiative, the CIA tried to convince key Chilean military officers to carry out a coup.Project FUBELTSeptember 1970, the CIA used false flag operatives to approach Chilean military officers, to persuade them to carry out a coup but, they have to removing Allende’s Gen. René Schneider. Formed by former two Generals and an former admirals. On 22 October, those three guys are go-ahead to kidnap Schneider. Schneider trying to protect himself from kidnap attempt but he got shot in his vital area, he died 3 days later.1973 Chilean coup d'étatLeadership of the Navy was transferred to José Toribio Merino, planner of the coup d’état and executive officer to Adm. Montero. Augusto Pinochet, General of the Army, and Gustavo Leigh, General of the Air Force, did not answer Allende's telephone calls to them (from Wikipedia)Despite evidence that all branches of the Chilean armed forces were involved in the coup, Allende hoped that some units remained loyal to the government. Allende was convinced of Pinochet's loyalty, telling a reporter that the coup d’état leaders must have imprisoned the general. Only at 8:30 am, when the armed forces declared their control of Chile and that Allende was deposed, did the president grasp the magnitude of the military's rebellion. Despite the lack of any military support, Allende refused to resign his office.Chilean Air Force aircraft soon arrived to provide close air support for the assault (by bombing the Palace). Afterwards, first reports said the 65-year-old president had died fighting troops, but later police sources reported he had committed suicide.Augusto Pinochet Into Power after coup d’etatJunta cleaned the constitutional Allende’s governmentsNew government gathered up thousands of people and held them in the national stadium where many were killed. This was followed by brutal repression during Pinochet's rule, during which about 3,000 people were killed, and more than 1,000 are still missing.He’s not exactly a dictator because he was elected through election, but the U.S seen him as dangerous person (for their geopolitical interest) and dictator as well..

Yeah, there's someone from the present times who would be called a 'dictator' by some.  Meet Paul Kagame[1], the president of small African nation of Rwanda. He's been in the office since 2000, after taking power from one of his puppets who had ruled the country since 1994. A 20-year rule in any democracy would be taken suspiciously, and there are allegations against his government of rigging up elections. But his countrymen love him, and his work shows why. He took over the war-torn country after a devastating civil war that led the deaths of over a million people.  People escape Rwanda, early 1990s Rwandan Civil War Paul commanded the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) against the government forces of Rwanda. The RPF was formed because of continued killing of the Tutsi minority by the Hutu government of Rwanda. The government believed in ethnic cleansing of their country and the Hutus were encouraged to kill the Tutsis in their neighborhood. This led to hundreds of thousands of Tutsis seeking refuge in Uganda and elsewhere. Those who stayed in the country were forced into barbaric genocide by the state.  Paul leading the RPF in the Rwandan Civil War, 1994 The RPF, under the leadership of the present president of Rwanda began advancing deep into the country. They soon took over the capital Kigali, and the government fled to Zaire anticipating prosecution by the victor forces. This war ended the genocide, and the victor RPF was then tasked into rebuilding the damaged infrastructure. Presidency The previous regime had carried away all the movable assets and the currencies stored in their treasury when they fled the country. The entire country was in shambles, with rampant STIs, devastated infrastructure, and the mass ridden in poverty. The first thing he did after the civil war was to enforce law and system in the country. He then proceeded to remove the ethnicity columns in the citizenship cards — He blamed the ethnic divide solely for the civil war. This erased the boundaries between the Hutu and Tutsi tribes, and helped calm the animosity between them. His government has since led massive infrastructural changes in the country.  Their capital city has been ranked one of the most popular destinations in Africa.The economic growth of the country was stable at decent 6–8% during the last decade.Schools were opened in a big literacy campaign and health infrastructure was improved.Today, they are constantly ranked good at ease of doing business.The country is excelling at tourism with one of the lowest crime rates in all of Africa.They have some of the lowest corruption levels in the continentFemales constitute 60% of their government.Now, some images :  Kigali, capital of the country.  Mara Smartphones — Africa's first indigenous smartphone company based in Rwanda  Volkswagen Plant in the country  I'm highly impressed by the transformation his governance has brought to what was once governed by a genocidal and rogue authority. The journey of the country continues to be an inspiration to all of Africa — on how to raise your health, economy and infrastructure from scratch, despite all odds. Originally answered : Has there ever been a good dictator at any point in history? Yes, and it doesn't matter if they're dictators as such, if they're delivering on good governance and prosperity of their people. Footnotes[1] Kagame's Rwanda is still Africa's most inspiring success story

I'm really surprised that nobody mentioned Adolf Hitler. Hitler Beyond the shadow of a doubt would easily qualify as not only one of the most popular dictators of all-time, but one of the most honorable, respected and loved by his country and neighboring Austria at his peak. Hitler is still respected even today at the astonishment of many not only by illiterate bikers and Skinhead racist but by genuine scholars and Revisionists (although not in Germany) definitely in South Korea, Thailand, Japan. In India deservingly so, as Hitler has been credited by many Historians (which include Indian Historians such as Dr. Summit Kamar PhD ) as the liberator of India from the British Empire, as well as liberator of Croatia. Adolf Hitler falls in the category you describe as “something people really needed.” As many of you may know, after WWI Germany was the shame of Europe as it had been accredited instigators of a war they hadn't started as well as sole responsibility for the damages of the war with the signing of The Treaty of Versailles. The German army suffered terribly during the first world war. And, the German nation also suffered terribly; especially after the war. The crippling sanctions enacted by the victors with the Treaty of Versailles threw the country into serious depression. There was chaos on the streets and anarchy in the air. Communists seized many cities, including Berlin. While the great wealth of the nation was fled away with outrageous war reparations, or sucked out by unscrupulous politicians. The average German was impoverished. Inflation and unemployment soon followed, and they destroyed all hope, all confidence, all morality. German cities were awash in pornography and prostitution, with even starving children being bought and sold like they were sex toys. Crime was rampant, drunkenness and drug addiction were wide spread. Suicide rates soared. The situation seemed hopeless...and then, things changed...dramatically! Soon after the National Socialists were elected, the economy sprang to life. Unemployment was erased, building boomed, great projects began. Confidence burst to life anew, after years of hunger, hardship and degradation Germany became a happy, hopeful nation again. Germany's transformation from squander in misery to a world superpower was so incredible that the 1938 edition of "Time magazine" named Adolf Hitler Man of the Year, additionally Hitler would also be nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize. To many it seemed as if a new cultural and political Renaissance was in store for all of Europe. But, others throughout the World, envious, powerful and above all fearful worked night and day to work Germany down. The second World War was the most deadliest and destructive war in history. For six long years the unequal struggle pinning Germany against the world continued. First one side then the other, on top. But, at last overwhelmed. Germany was once more defeated. This time, however, The Reich was to be punished not with reparations nor loss of land. Nor, with simple decadence and despair. No. This time, Germany was to be subjected to pure hatred. Hatred, of the most vicious, depraved kind imaginable. Millions upon millions of Germans, many of whom had nothing to do with the war were systematically, raped, tortured and slaughtered. All in the most sickening ways imaginable. What happened to Germany and it's people during and after WWII has remained the darkest and best kept secret in world history. NSDAP innovations and projects: When Adolf Hitler assumed power in 1933, there were 7 million unemployed Germans, the highest per capita rate in Europe at the time. In only his first year in office, an unprecedented 3,374,000 were helped back to work. Hitler's brilliant and innovative ideas included building motorways the length and breadth of the country, with housing units provided for workers. The workers' families would then eagerly spend the newly earned wages contributing to a fast growing economy. Priority was given to the health and fitness of the nation, especially the youth. Free health care and generous financial support were provided for expectant mothers. The world's first anti-smoking campaign were also introduced. In addition, it was now government policy to protect the environment and wildlife. Crime was virtually eliminated, with streets made safe to walk on again. Workers subsided by the government would take holidays abroad. Hitler is the first in Europe to introduce the 40-Hour work week, with extra pay for overtime. Factories are now required to provide workers with restrooms and a cafeteria. The NSDAP leadership looked upon the charging of interest on loans as immoral, and by forcing banks to abolish the practice of usury, millions were freed from the slavery of debt. It was a spectacular financial recovery not witnessed before or since, and often referred to as the greatest economic miracle of all time. Meanwhile, most western countries still mired in the Great Depression.

Former President of South Korea Park Chung Hee should be added to this list. I will admit here that this man did commit many outright human rights violations and did kill many innocent people for being opposed to him, but like many other Koreans, the one thing we will never forget is how he saved South Korea from chaos and economic ruin and turned it from a desperately poor nation to one of the richest nations in the world. In fact, the Korean Gallup polls indicate that he was the most popular president of Korea and TIME also named him one of the Asians of the Century in the 90s.  Before Park overthrew the democratic Korean government in 1961, South Korea was a desperately poor and agrarian nation that suffered through years of colonization and war. Korea in those days had the same GDP as modern day Congo and dying of starvation was common. North Korea also surpassed South Korea in many ways and so South Korea faced many threats. The democratically elected government was corrupt and mired in self interest that no progress could actually be made and many Koreans suffered while the politicians were useless in solving the nation's problems.  In 1961, Park, through a coup d'etat, took power, though he did go through the democratic process 3 times and won all campaigns. He promised the Korean people that he would bring prosperity and stuck by it. He was very harsh as he established the KCIA, took away many freedoms, and harshly punished the opposition especially Communist sympathizers. He ruled the nation with an iron fist until he was assassinated in 1979 but through those times, he made an impact that will never be forgotten.  Despite some blatant violations, he planted the seeds of industrialization and development by subsidizing the many modern conglomerates and creating new industries that brought South Korea away from its agrarian roots. He also further developed the nation through his many projects, which modernized many industries and increased the quality of life for many South Koreans. Despite the fact that South Korea was desperately poor especially since the US cut off aid, Park managed to get West Germany and Japan to invest in South Korea, with the money going directly into the economy.  He also strengthened the Korean military by sending Korean soldiers to Vietnam. South Korea sent more troops to Vietnam than any other nation other than the US during the Vietnam War. It might not be smart getting involved in a war especially with a developing economy, but the logic behind this is very reasonable. The US paid South Korean soldiers to fight in the war, which meant the influx of foreign currency to help contribute to development. The US also provided South Korea with modernized weaponry, which South Korea desperately needed especially since the North was a very great threat.  Park was not perfect at all and I will not deny that some of his policies did cause innocent Koreans to suffer, but he did much more for the Korean people than any democratically elected leader. Because of what he did, I would call Park a good dictator especially since many other dictators never had that devotion to the nation like Park did.

Being an economist, and not a historian, the economic miracle that economists point to is South Korea under Park Chung-hee (Park Jung Hee alt older spelling).  Even though he ran a ruthless dictatorship with little regard for human rights, he actually promoted one of the most rapid growth periods of any country in history.  Usually dictatorships are so concerned with concentrating power and extracting wealth for themselves and their cronies at the expense of the other citizens and economic growth.  The process of a dictatorship concentrating power usually distorts the incentive structure of economic activity, and with distorted incentives usually the economy performs very poorly.  However Park despite all of his other dictatorial faults was able to create an economic miracle for the country. Park Chung-hee ([박정희] 14 November 1917 – 26 October 1979) was a South Korean president, and military general who led South Korea from 1961 until his assassination in 1979. Park seized power through the May 16 coup, a military coup d'état that overthrew the Second Republic of South Korea in 1961 and ruled as a military strongman at the head of the Supreme Council for National Reconstruction until his election and inauguration as the President of the Third Republic of South Korea in 1963. In 1972, Park declared martial law and recast the constitution into a highly authoritarian document, ushering in the Fourth Republic of South Korea. After surviving several assassination attempts, including two operations associated with North Korea, Park was eventually assassinated on 26 October 1979 by Kim Jae-gyu, the chief of his own security services.  He had led South Korea for 18 years. Park's first-born daughter, Park Geun-hye, is the current President of South Korea.  In 1960, a student uprising (the "April 19 Revolution") led to the resignation of the autocratic, corrupt President Syngman Rhee. A period of political instability followed, broken by General Park Chung-hee's May 16 coup against the weak and ineffectual government the next year. Park took over as president until his assassination in 1979, overseeing rapid export-led economic growth as well as implementing political repression. Park was heavily criticized as a ruthless military dictator, who in 1972 extended his rule by creating a new constitution, which gave the president sweeping (almost dictatorial) powers and permitted him to run for an unlimited number of six-year terms. However, the Korean economy developed significantly during Park's tenure and the government developed the nationwide expressway system, the Seoul subway system, and laid the foundation for economic development during his 17-year tenure. ... South Korea's market economy ranks 13th in the world by both nominal and purchasing power parity GDP, identifying it as one of the G-20 major economies. It is a developed country with a high-income economy and is the most industrialized member country of the OECD.   South Korea's economy was one of the world's fastest-growing from the early 1960s to the late 1990s, and South Korea is still one of the fastest-growing developed countries in the 2000s, along with Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan, the other three Asian Tigers.  South Koreans refer to this growth as the Miracle on the Han River.  The South Korean economy is heavily dependent on international trade, and in 2014, South Korea was the 5th largest exporter and 7th largest importer in the world.  The Miracle on the Han River is a term coined in the late 1950s to describe the rapid economic growth of South Korea following the Korean War, transforming from a developing country to a developed country. The term has also come to describable the rapid reconstruction and development of the economy of South Korea, leading to events such as the successful hosting of the 1988 Summer Olympics and co-hosting of the 2002 FIFA World Cup, as well as the prosperity of chaebols (family owned conglomerates), such as Samsung, LG, and Hyundai.... Today, South Korea is often mentioned a role model for many developing countries in Asia. Dictators and dictatorships are highly subjective and diverse. These are regimes based largely on political circumstance. By dictator, I would assume exclusion of kings, whose reigns are mostly defined by their legitimacy. Some dictators can do many good things to their state. However, it is disadvantageous in the long run because the system becomes too dependent on them; and their successor most likely unfit to meet the expectations of his predecessor. The first “good” dictator that comes to mind is Napoleon Bonaparte. He made several important reforms in France, forever changed European politics, and revolutionized warfare. At the same time, he was tyrannical and so was his empire, and he eventually served to become a tremendous example of the downfall spurred by human pride and ambition. Another important dictator is Robespierre. Despite the many men he was responsible for killing, he, in my opinion, was the true hero and champion of the revolution. “Terror without virtue is fatal; virtue without terror is impotent” “Any law which violates the inalienable rights of man is essentially unjust and tyrannical; it is not a law at all” He was a very interesting and complex character. One should not forget the Roman dictators. They were given power during times of great crisis. Most of them were virtuous, imposing, and highly skilled. Cincinnatus is most well-known (aside from Caesar), and my personal favorite is Fabius.  Sulla, the first “Caesar”, who fought in a Roman civil war against Marius, won, and occupied Rome with his army. He willingly gave up his dictatorial power and died soon afterwards. Julius Caesar was a young man when Sulla came and ruled in Rome. Caesar was recognized by Sulla and even predicted Caesar’s greatness. So, yes, I think that there are good dictators - or does that make responsible decisions for the benefit for their country. We must not forget that dictators are leaders just as much as those of different forms of government, and that their actions are subjective and done greatly based on the circumstances surrounding them.

Dictator. We have very negative connotations of the word. It brings to mind oppressive regimes, the suffering of the masses, the power of one over all. But there’s nothing inherently wrong with dictatorships – in fact many will suggest that the best political system, for everyone, is a dictatorship. That is if, of course, if the dictator is benevolent; kind, caring, and working for the good of the people. Some of the dictators name are listed below Simon Boliver He was born in Caracas the capital of Venezuela. Bolívar witnessed the coronation of Napoleon in Notre Dama, an event that left a profound impression on him. The Latin American independence movement was launched a year after Bolívar’s return, as Napoleon’s invasion of Spain unsettled Spanish authority. Napoleon also failed completely in his attempt to gain the support of the Spanish colonies, which claimed the right to nominate their own officials. To obtain help from rhe British, Bolívar was sent on a mission to London, where he arrived in July. His assignment was to explain to England the plight of the revolutionary colony, to gain recognition for it, and to obtain arms and support. But he was not successful. When Venezuela’s independence was declared on July 5, 1811, Bolívar entered the army of the young republic, whose commander in chief was Miranda. But later an armistice was signed in July 1812 that left the entire country at the mercy of Spain. In a sweeping hard-fought campaign, he vanquished the royalists in six pitched battles and on August 6, 1813, entered Caracas. He was given the title of Liberator and assumed political dictatorship. The war of independence was however just the beginning. Bolívar turned his energies toward gaining support from Great Britain, and, in an effort to convince the British people of their stake in the freedom of the Spanish colonies. In the crucial Battle of Boyacá on August 7, 1819, the bulk of the royalist army surrendered ultimately to Bolívar. The Republic of Colombia, usually called Gran Colombia, was established, three days later comprising the three departments of New Granada (now the countries of Colombia and Panama), Venezuela, and Quito (Ecuador). The territory of Gran Colombia had now been completely recovered from Spain, and its new government was recognized by the United States. Only Peru and Upper Peru remained in the hands of the Spaniards. However on December 9, 1824, the Spanish viceroy lost the Battle of Ayacucho to Sucre and surrendered with his entire army. Bolívar is regarded by many as the greatest genius the Latin America has produced. He was a man of international renown in his own day, and his reputation has steadily increased since his death. There are few figures in European history and none in the history of the United States who display the rare combination of strength and weakness, character and temperament, prophetic vision and poetic power that distinguish Simón Bolívar. Still he is remembered by both East and the West as the George Washington of South America. As much as I dislike dictatorship, I will succumb to the temptation and name Peisistratus (Greek: Πεισίστρατος/Peisistratos), a tyrant of Archaic Athens in the 6th century BCE.  He was some years younger that Solon, whose laws had placated Athens but had also disappointed both the higher and the lower social classes—each for their own reasons. He became quite popular when he captured Nisaea in a war between Athens and Megara.  Being ambitious, he exploited the turmoil to institute a tyranny; twice he tried, using some pretty smart tricks (see below), and twice he failed and was exiled. At last, in 545 BCE, his third coup was succesful; he managed to remain in power for the rest of his life. He died loved by most Atheneans. His rule was very temperate and moderate, as both Herodotus and Aristotle relate. He didn't abolish the democratic institutions and archonships, he showed respect to the old customs and didn't nullify Solon's laws. He cut taxes for the lower classes and distributed land to the landless. He even instituted a system of "traveling judges" who would try cases in the countryside. The masses were quite happy with him in power. Regarding economy, he strengthened both agriculture and commerce, making Athens a rich city. His most important work, though, was his campaign to beautify and modernize Athens. He built the first aqueduct, the Enneakrounos (a great fountain), the Hekatompedon (a temple on the Acropolis) and the first part of the temple of Olympian Zeus. He inaugurated or greatly subsidized the Panathenaic Games and festivals like the Dionysia, which came to be of pan-Hellenic amplitude some years later. It was also during his reign that the Homeric epics were first written down; the Iliad and the Odyssey as we know them today were solidified then. A bonus story: In his second attempt to take power, he found a tall and handsome woman, dressed her in an armour and had her stand beside him on his chariot. A lot of Atheneans believed that Athena herself, the patron goddess of Athens, was his guide.

And the policies of his administration were more favorable to most of the population under his power/influence: «During 1972, the macroeconomic problems continued to mount. Inflation surpassed 200 percent, and the fiscal deficit surpassed 13 percent of GDP. Domestic credit to the public sector grew at almost 300 percent, and international reserves dipped below US$77 million. Real wages fell 25 percent in 1972»https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_history_of_Chile#Statism_and_collectivism_.281970.E2.80.9373.29 «The Vuskovic Plan was the basis for the economic policy of the Popular Unity (UP) government of Chilean President Salvador Allende. It was drafted by and named after his first Economics Minister Pedro Vuskovic, who had worked before with the CEPAL. Although good results were obtained in 1970, hyperinflation made a come-back in 1972. By 1973, Chile was in shambles – inflation was hundreds of percents, the country had no foreign reserves, and GDP was falling.»https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vuskovic_plan «The first year saw 12% industrial growth and an 8.6% increase in GDP, accompanied by major declines in inflation (down from 34.9% to 22.1%) and unemployment (down to 3.8%).[citation needed] In addition to the rise in employment, Allende also raised wages on a number of occasions throughout 1970 and 1971. These rises in wages were negated by continuing increases in prices for food. Although price rises had also been high under president Eduardo Frei Montalva (27% a year between 1967 and 1970), a basic basket of consumer goods rose by 120% from 190 to 421 escudos in one month alone, August 1972. In the period 1970–72, while Allende was in government, exports fell 24% and imports rose 26%, with imports of food rising an estimated 149%. Although nominal wages were rising, there was not a commensurate increase in the standard of living for the Chilean population.[…]In 1972 the escudo had runaway inflation of 140%. From December 1972 to December 1973, the inflation rate was a catastrophic 508% – an example of hyperinflation. The average Real GDP contracted between 1971 and 1973 at an annual rate of 5.6% ("negative growth"), and the government's fiscal deficit soared while foreign reserves declined. Inflation led to the rise of black markets in rice, beans, sugar, and flour, and a "disappearance" of such basic commodities from supermarket shelves. The government attempted to prevent this shortage by creating juntas de Abastecimientos y Precios. In addition to the hyperinflation and the fall in the value of copper, the lack of economic aid further depressed the economy. The growth in GDP went from 9% in 1971 to −1.2% in 1972, while the rate of inflation went from 22.1% the previous year to 163.4%. Vuskovic was replaced as Minister of Economy on June 17, 1972, and the Allende government announced it would default on debts owed to international creditors and foreign governments. Allende also froze all prices while raising salaries, but the damage was already done. Chile had entered a major recession, with hyperinflation, a negative growth in GDP, a lack of supplies and spare parts, as well as a state of general political and social disorder. His implementation of these policies led to strong opposition by landowners, some middle-class sectors, the rightist National Party, the Roman Catholic Church (which was displeased with the direction of the educational policy), and eventually the Christian Democrats. By September 1973, inflation had reached 381.1% and the growth in GDP stood at −4.2%.»https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vuskovic_plan#Results «The overall stated objective of Allende's Popular Unity government was to achieve a transition to socialism by democratic means. This would involve a combined political and economic program aimed at wresting control of the economy out of the hands of business owners and placing it in the hands of the state. It would then be easier to dismantle the various institutions connected with Western capitalism. The key figure in the economic policy of Salvador Allende’s UP government was the first Minister of the Economy, Pedro Vuskovic. In accordance with Keynesian economics, he wanted to implement a massive redistribution of revenue by raising salaries and increasing public expenditure, through which the buying power of the population would increase and accordingly consumption in general. These measures would activate the idle capacity of the Chilean productive apparatus (which was relatively large) and generate a climate of prosperity. If this strategy paid off, it would have had the effect of strengthening the government’s position and allowing it to advance its revolutionary program much faster. The macroeconomic program was based on several key assumptions, the most important being that the manufacturing sector had ample underutilized capacity. The lack of full utilization was, in turn, attributed to two fundamental factors: the monopolistic nature of the manufacturing industry and the structure of income distribution. Based on this diagnosis, influenced by Keynesian ideas of support to aggregate demand, it was thought that if income were redistributed toward the poorer groups through wage increases and if prices were properly controlled, there would be a significant expansion of demand and output.[citation needed] This provided the theoretical basis for the belief that large fiscal deficits would not necessarily be inflationary. Regarding inflation, the UP program placed blame on structural rigidities (namely, slow or no response of quantity supplied to price increases), bottlenecks, and the role of monopolistic pricing, and it played down the role of fiscal pressures and money creation.»en.wikipedia.org - Vuskovic plan - Wikipedia

During the 1950s,  my country Venezuela was under the rule of this man.  He is Marcos Pérez Jiménez, and he made this country one of the best in the world at the time. He was member of a military junta that took power in the country after a bloodless coup in 1948, but he took power by himself in 1952, and he remained in power untill 1958. This period of our history is known as "the dictatorship of concrete", because under the rule of Perez Jimenez, the country experienced a development and economic boom like never before in its history. Here are some videos about Venezuela at that time.   During this period, the country built the largest cable car in the world, " El Teléferico de Mérida", the Mérida cable car, which since 2008 is out of service.  He also started the construction of many of the countries highways and superhighways, which were among the best of the world at the time.   This is a short video of when the highways were being built.  To prevent the formation of more slums, and to eliminate the ones that already existed, which were mainly inhabited by the working class, he started the construction of "Los Superbloques", the Superblocks, which were massive buildings designed to house hundreds of families.     After he was overthrown, the new Democratic governments stopped the construction of more of this buildings and basically said to the working class, You fuck off and go build slums, we don't want you here. So thanks to them is basically why today we have this   He also started the construction of the Bridge over the Maracaibo Lake. The bridge over the Maracaibo Lake, which is the biggest lake in South America, was finished in 1962, 5 years after he was overthrown.  He also built a lot of buildings with innovative designs in Caracas, all in a push to modernize the city Gym of the Central University of Venezuela  The Helicoide  The Humboldt Hotel and the Avila Cable car  Los Procéres  The Towers of El Silencio  And many, many more. His government is also remembered as one of the most safe in terms of crime. There was repression but it was mainly against political dissidents, so if you were an ordinary person and stayed out of politics, you weren't affected by any of that. He was a true nationalist, and he had plans to recover the land that Venezuela had lost during the past century. He was overthrown in 1958, and he later died in Spain.  He did more in 6 years for this country than what 40 years of democracy and 18 years and counting of "Socialist Bolivarian Revolution" ever did.

Has there ever been a "good dictatorship"? Is human kind capable of doing so?Dictators, have have roots in the Roman Republic. The office of Dictator was an emergency measure and was democratically elected and ratified by the Senate in dire times when the usual deadlocks of Roman politics could not be afforded.  For six months the Dictator held absolute power, with no checks from the Senate or the people, and at the end of this period the dictator would return his power to the Senate. Believe it or not, for nearly five hundred years, until the waning days of the Republic, each of them stepped down. One such dictator was Quintus Fabius Maximus. He was elected after Rome had suffered two disastrous defeats at the hands of Hannibal. This man, Fabius, is considered the father of Guerilla warfare and used it along with what we, today, call Fabian tactics to control Hannibal. He is the only man, other than Scippio who didn't suffer a series of disastrous defeats against Hannibal. Against immense opposition and calls for his head, because of his cowardly tactics of never giving open battle, this guy did his best to prevent another disaster. Fabius was one in a line of "good" dictators, many of them might have been unpopular in their day, but they served The Senate and People of Rome. In modern times, the former President of Yugoslavia, Josip Broz Tito, is an example of a benevolent dictator. This communist leader, split off from the Soviet union (read Stalin)was well liked by both the power-blocs and was one of the chief leaders of the Non-aligned Movement, among other things.

Meet Sheikh Hasina, prime minister of Bangladesh.  Ms. Hasina would probably never agree that she is a dictator. After all she is only a prime minister elected by the party that was elected in a popular election. It would not be admitted that only her own party and a handful parties funded and aided by her party contested in the election. She also would tell you that it is the law that has interned almost all significant opposition leaders, and had some of them hung until death. She has nothing to do with any of that. May be she is right. May be she is not. But, she is the source of all power in Bangladesh. Her decade long rule, punctuated by a short military interval, has brought prosperity and development to Bangladesh at an unimaginable scale. 6%-7% year on year GDP growth for years, achieving half the MDGs with flying colours, suppressing a massive militant threat with ruthless efficiency, reduction in child mortality, maternal mortality, diarrhoea dearth, population growth, child marriage, dowry, carbon emission… and increase in literacy, school enrolment, women’s participation in labour force, formal health service coverage, immunisation, connectivity, productivity, mobility, electricity, calorie intake, dietary diversity, family planning… as well as stability. One of the poorest countries a decade back, once known in the US as a “bottomless basket”, Bangladesh now has gained the status of a lower middle income country, and an emerging tiger. The country that was not even connected by roads three decades back now has submarines, a satellite, m-money, and e-governance. While developing the biggest and most equipped military force in history of the country (She has warships made in Bangladesh now), she consistently maintained a highly congenial diplomatic regime. Bangladesh is a friend to everyone and an enemy to none (barring Israel, with which Bangladesh still doesn't have a diplomatic relation). She solves her international problems by diplomacy and international courts, not violence, verbal or otherwise. Bangladesh is also now the source of ground troops for UN peacekeepers. On top of it, she runs one of the few functional Muslim countries that can claim to be moderate Muslim. Despite the rise of Wahhabi pressure within Bangladesh she has managed to encourage and promote a secular Bengali culture. Her anti militancy tactics are not always ethical, but they are, as of now, extremely effective. She has survived at least a dozen assassination attempts, including one that killed tens of her party leadership. Do I like her? Oh yes. I'd say contemporary Africa gives good examples of how ambiguous a dictatorship can be.  A lot of African former leaders get a lot of credit today for what they did. Kwame Nkrumah in Ghana, Sekou Toure in Guinea, Haile Selassie in Ethiopia, Nasser, Bourguiba, Nyerere and many others are presented as the founding fathers of the continent.  The fact is that these leaders detained members of the opposition, failed to address famines and corruption, never achieved continental cooperation, did not respect basic democratic rules and provoked internal conflicts. Yet, they remain immensely popular.  What happened in most cases is that these leaders had to face two things. Diplomatic tensions due to the cold war, underdeveloped and uncompetitive economy. Only the first issue was addressed, which led to economic failure, one-party system, protests.  This happened a few decades ago. If these leaders are remembered today, it's for the diplomatic battles they fought. African independence, United States of Africa, anti-imperialism...  My point is : it takes some time to forget the bad deeds of dictators. But if they played their cards properly, they leave a long-lasting mark. Some may even be regarded as "good" dictators, because their battles transcended the rest.  If you believe that some superior ideas or concepts are worth undermining human rights then you can consider these people "good" dictators.

From the oldest country in Europe comes the most humble of dictators and one with the longest time in office on the past century, I present you Salazar.  Few in Europe would imagine that last century Portugal got ruled by a dictator for 36 years. During that time: the country paid in full the debts from WW1avoided entering into WW2stopped Spain from joining WW2 Axis and controlling west Europethe country accumulated gold in comparable scale to Switzerlandco-founded NATO to stop communist advance in Europe.Died of old age with his successor in place. Lived like a true uncle scrooge, without known luxuries, without known riches even as we speak today. This was a man with a mission in mind. His own life is nothing short of extraordinary. Studied to become a priest, became the dean at one of the oldest universities in the world. When the military took power in 1926, the new government was delivered to the only person they would trust as honest. This was the university dean from which many of the military had come to admire from their student times in academia. Salazar duly performed his assigned mission until death by old age in 1968. Very rare for a long-lasting dictator (36 years) to die of old-age without amassing wealth. That was Salazar, his money-saving policies were so legendary strict that he had a separate electricity counter downstairs where political meetings took place and another one upstairs for his personal sleeping room that was paid from his own pocket. After Salazar's death, his family was left to bitter years of discussion over his only noteworthy possession, an old farm house in the middle of the mountains. Such a small house by any standards that the whole show ended up becoming a national joke on the media. In 2007, almost 40 years after his death, this same dictator still got voted as "the greatest Portuguese who ever lived". In large part because since his ruling one would see Portugal losing its global impact and being today considered as a poor European nation depending on others. In significant part this is due to the ongoing rampant corruption across political circles (lesson learned that we probably needed this dictator just to keep wealthy families far from seizing control). Interesting to mention that its political opponents were the communist sponsored parties. When the communist party leader, Àlvaro Cunhal was arrested, he was still allowed to study at university for a PhD. He could literally walk out of jail every single day, but always came back so that he could fight the system legally. The jury for his thesis defense was the same person who later in time became the country's prime-minister, Marcelo Caetano, which as juri president approved the thesis of this communist leader with a good grade. Marcelo himself was a respected figure before acceding to government, due to his effort in reforming the legal system in Portugal. In some similarity to what Napoleon had done earlier in France, so he took pride in the impartiality between politics and justice. Therefore, it is interesting to note the existing mutual respect between political adversaries at this period of time. A few years down the road in 1974 saw the communists taking the government power in Portugal through a revolution and this same Álvaro de Cunhal then permitted Marcelo to peacefully exit the Portugal to live his old age days in Brazil. This is the mindset of peacefulness still exists today in Portugal, one of the few places where that same dramatic revolution (1974) literally happened with flowers on the barrel of guns, to prevent anyone from shooting and hurting others. This is Portugal. Still one heck of a good place to live. Try it out. :-)

Whenever the word 'dictator' has been invoked to flex its muscles by the noble minds from any point of time following the year 44BC, a name has always rose to the occasion in shining armor. Julius Caesar, a fierce commander and a sensible senator. A man who was known for his might and mind equally, the one who held both the dictatorship and the tribunate. A man who in his death was granted the title of Divus Iulius (The Divine Julius). A man who was bewitched by a woman who surpassed all the beauty and wittiness(Cleopatra). A man who was cherished, feared, reproached, respected and alas, deceived and murdered in cold-blood by some staunch senators in the sacrosanct senate. Man who has eventually lived through the veins of Rome and every Roman, and through the innumerable eulogies and elegies written after him. Julius Caesar was first appointed dictator in 49 BC but resigned his dictatorship within 11 days. In 48 BC, he was reappointed dictator, only this time for an indefinite period, and in 46 BC, he was appointed dictator for 10 years Under his command Rome flourished and thrived for greater prosperity and opulence. He brought and executed many notable changes in the functioning of Rome.  When he took over Rome, it was laden in debts over and across, so he ordered a census be taken, which forced a reduction in the grain dole, and that jurors could only come from the Senate or the equestrian ranks. Caesar also tightly regulated the purchase of state-subsidized grain and reduced the number of recipients to a fixed number, all of whom were entered into a special register. He passed a sumptuary law that restricted the purchase of certain luxuries. Hereafter, he passed a law that rewarded families for having many children, so as to haste the population growth of Italy.  Then, he outlawed professional guilds, except those of ancient foundation, since many of these were subversive political clubs.  He then passed a term-limit law applicable to governors.  He passed a debt-restructuring law, which ultimately eliminated about a fourth of all debts owed. From 47 to 44 BC, he made plans for the distribution of land to about 15,000 of his veterans. The most remarkable change he brought was in the calendar. The calendar was then based on the movement of moon. Caesar replaced this calendar with the Egyptian calendar, which was then modulated by the movement of sun. He set the length of the year to 365.25 days by adding an intercalary day at the end of February every fourth year (29th Feb). To bring the calendar into alignment with the seasons, he decreed that three extra months be inserted into 46 BC (the ordinary intercalary month at the end of February, and two extra months after November). Thus, the Julian Calendar came to existence 1 January 45 BC. This calendar is almost identical to the present Western Calendar. Shortly before his assassination, he passed a few more reforms. He established a police force, appointed officials to carry out his land reforms, and ordered the rebuilding of Carthage and Corinth. He also extended Latin rights throughout the Roman world, and then abolished the tax system and reverted to the earlier version that allowed cities to collect tribute however they wanted, rather than needing Roman intermediaries. His assassination dashed further and larger schemes, which included the construction of an unprecedented temple to Mars, a huge theater, and a library on the scale of the Library of Alexandria. He also wanted to convert Ostia to a major port, and cut a canal through the Isthmus of Corinth. Militarily, he wanted to conquer the Dacians and Parthians, and avenge the loss at Carrhae. Thus, he instituted a massive mobilization. Shortly before his assassination, the Senate named him censor for life and Father of the Fatherland, and the month of Quintilis was renamed July in his honor. After his death, coins were issued in his honor bearing his image and his statue was placed next to those of the kings. He was granted a golden chair in the Senate, was allowed to wear triumphal dress whenever he chose, and was offered a form of semiofficial or popular cult, with Mark Antony as his high priest.

Some dictators have voluntarily given up their reins for the benefit of their nation.  They are an exception to the power corrupts paradigm, and have put the needs of the nation above power. Juan Carlos I of Spain was groomed as Franco's successor.  He inherited an authoritarian state, but quickly moved towards liberalizing the government in the Spanish transition to democracy. Diocletian noticed that many of the Roman Empire's problems arise due to interregnal instability.  Newly minted emperors fight succession wars, and there are cases of multiple successions within a short period of time.  To combat this, he instituted the Diarchy and then the Tetrarchy.  The tetrarchy, in particular, had two junior co-emperors who would be groomed to take over the emperorship, hopefully avoiding any complex succession issues.  To cement the correct Tetrarchy transition, Diocletian himself retired to his country estate.  While the tetrarchy did not work out in the end, Diocletian still sacrificed his power nobly in order to better the state. George Washington was the president of the United States.  While he clearly was not a dictator, he could have become one.  George Washington was immensely popular, and the USA did not yet have the precedent for peaceful governmental transitions.  Washington's (and also Adams's) decisions to peacefully step down cemented the democratic tradition in the US at a cost to their own power.

In the days of the Roman republic, dictatorship was temporary and bestowed by the two consuls of Rome only in times of a military emergency, or to carry out a specific tasks, after which they were obligated to step down. Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus was an ex-consul (the highest office in the republic) and an experienced politician. He was made dictator in 459 BC after, during a war against neighbouring italic peoples, the Aequi and Sabines, a Roman army had been surrounded and besieged. Cincinnatus was called out of retirement on his farm to fight the Aequi, defeating them at the battle of Mons Algidus. Forcing the Aequi people to surrender as opposed to slaughtering and enslaving them which was common practice. As soon as he had succeeded, Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus gave up supreme dictatorial power and retired to his farm for a second time after having had it for 15 days. Cincinnatus was granted dictatorship a second time in 439 BC to thwart an alleged coup attempt plotted by Spurius Maelius, planning on restoring the Roman monarchy. When he sent for Maelius to be arrested he was killed trying to escape and his ambitions of kingship died with him. Immediately after the issue was resolved, Cincinnatus retired for the third time, and for good. He would die 9 years later, a paragon of civic virtue for Romans to aspire to for centuries afterwards.

This is a very slippery slope. There are a lot of dictators who demonstrably improved their country's standard of living and brought stability to a country in chaos. In fact, there aren't many dictators that don't accomplish at least one or the other, because if they fail to do either, they don't last very long. The question is whether or not the benefits of the dictator's rule were worth the loss of civil liberties and often, repression that came along with it. Francisco Franco and Augusto Pinochet presided over massive economic growth in Spain (1939-75) and Chile (1973-90), respectively. But you'd find very few Spaniards or Chileans who think of them positively today, because of their harsh repression. Two former dictators who do have a largely positive reputation in their own countries today are Mustafa Kemal Ataturk (Turkey, 1922-38), and Harry Lee (aka Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore, 1959-90), who were both mentioned earlier. In both cases, those men were pretty much architects of their respective states, and were dictators by popular consent. The vast majority of the people they ruled wanted them to stay in power. At least in Lee's case (I'm not so certain about Ataturk), I have no doubt he would have relinquished his power if a majority of the people asked him to. It was never an issue in either case, anyway. Ataturk was massively re-elected as President, without rigging elections, anytime his renewal of mandate came up. What's more common is a legacy that's split down the middle, like in the case of Ioannis Metaxas (Greece, 1936-41). Metaxas brought stability and prosperity back to his country, and in the last months of his life, his civil and military leadership (Metaxas was a general in the Hellenic Army) resulted in Greece crushing an Italian invasion and driving the Italians back into occupied Albania. However, Metaxas was also a Fascist in his political views, and governed repressively against anyone who disagreed with him. Many Greeks on the political left ended up in jail under him. In modern Greece, opinions of him run the gamut from those who see him as a national hero, to those who revile him for his violation of civil liberties, to those who are ambivalent towards him, because he did many good and bad things. Others with such "mixed" legacies are people like Porfirio Diaz (Mexico, 1876-1911), Alberto Fujimori (Peru, 1990-2000) and even Fidel Castro (Cuba, 1959-2008), who despite all of the people who despise him, is still genuinely beloved by a great many Cuban people.
