My best guess for a benevolent dictator would be the Prussian doctor Johann Friedrich Struensee who used his position as physician to the mentally ill Christian VII of Denmark-Norway to gain absolute power over the kingdom for 16 months. Struensee had a beneficial effect on the mentally ill absolute monarch whose condition improved after Struensee became his physician. Struensee befriended the king and managed to outmaneuver the corrupt noblemen who had previously controlled the king. Struensee effectively made the king sign over all power to him and started a fast-paced programme of reforms inspired by enlightenment philosophy. Among the 1069 cabinet orders he issued during his 16-month rule were: Abolition of tortureAbolition of unfree corvéeAbolition of the censorship of the pressAbolition of the practice of preferring nobles for state officesAbolition of noble privilegesAbolition of "undeserved" revenues for noblesAbolition of the etiquette rules at the Royal CourtAbolition of the Royal Court's aristocracyAbolition of state funding of unproductive manufacturersAbolition of several holidaysIntroduction of a tax on gambling and luxury horses to fund nursing of foundlingsBanning slave trade in the Danish coloniesRewarding only actual achievements with feudal titles and decorationsCriminalization and punishment of briberyRe-organization of the judicial institutions to minimize corruptionIntroduction of state-owned granaries to balance out the grain priceAssignment of farmland to peasantsRe-organization and reduction of the armyUniversity reformsReform of the state-owned medical institutionsAbolition of the death penalty for theftHowever his fight against corruption and nepotism made him many powerful enemies. Also Struensee who conducted business in his native German and didn’t speak Danish was criticized for not respecting Danish and Norwegian traditions. Although initially favorable towards Struensee public opinion turned against him and the abolition of censorship resulted in a flood of anti-Struensee pamphlets. The public was not aware of the severity of the king’s mental illness and was outraged at how Struensee openly pushed the absolute monarch aside. This sentiment was confirmed when Struensee appointed him to the position of “Privy council minister” (gehejmekabinetsminister) with he power to issue cabinet orders with the same legal power as royal ordinances, even without the king’s signature. Furthermore public opinion turned on Struensee because of his at the time scandalous affair with queen Caroline Matilda. Also on some occation Struensee’s assistant Enevold Brandt got into a struggle with the mad king and ended up punching him in the face. All of this encouraged Struensee’s enemies and on Jauary 17th a palace coup took place led by members of the old elite centered around the conservative nobleman Ove Høegh-Guldberg and queen dowager Juliane Marie who hoped to advance the position of her son, the heir presumptive Frederick. Struensee, Brandt and Caroline Matilda was arrested and the conspirators behind the coup drove the king around Copenhagen in a golden chariot to show the public how he had been “liberated”. Struensee and Brandt were later tried and found guilty of lèse majesté and usurpation of the royal authority which were both capital offences under the Danish constitution of the time. Both men were executed on April 28th 1772. The queen was at first held prisoner at Kronborg castle but was later exiled to Germany. Although some of Struensee’s administrative and social reforms survived the coup the new reactionary regime undid many of the advances made. Torture was re-introduced, extramarital sex was re-criminalized, the officials sacked by Struensee was re-hired. The freedom of the press introduced by Struensee was severely limited by harsh penalties for offensive books.

The concept of a "benevolent dictator" has been around for millennia. However, no single person can come up with a political methodology that appeals to everyone. So the idea of a benevolent dictator might actually be impossible.    However, the idea that a benevolent dictator might exist for possibly creating the most good for the most people in his lands is far more viable.    There have been many kings, pharaohs, emperors, hegemons and rulers, who kept their people safe, generally prosperous, fed and entertained and also living in reasonably stable economic environments. There were even some who were intellectuals, artists, scientists and philosophers themselves.  On occasion, one would arise who would greatly contribute to a nation's cultural legacy. Such a man was Lorenzo De Medici. No doubt that Florence became culturally far richer due to Lorenzo.  Unfortunately, no one can lead any group of people without a strong and dominant ego. And people with strong egos usually grate on others with strong egos. Moreover, strong egos may develop into megalomania. The worst leaders in history were megalomaniacs and some were outright pathological. All of the great civilizations in history had their fair share of good and bad leaders.   I cannot attest to the actual truth or reality of his times, but Pericles of Athens may have come the closest any man in history has yet come to the personification of the benevolent dictator.

Frederick the Great Frederick the Great was the ruler of Prussia between 1740 and 1786 and was considered to be the embodiment of enlightened absolutism. At that time Prussia was a collection of territories, and by 1772, Frederick was able to unify them all under his power. He was a patron of art and culture and allowed considerable freedom of literature and press, unlike a dictator. He is known for personally leading his army in battles and often wore his old uniforms instead of a royal ensemble. He didn’t believe in the divine right of kings and instead took steps to consolidate his kingdom’s economy and administration. He had canals built and encouraged agriculture by draining swamps. He established a thousand villages which increased the flow of immigrants. He unified the kingdom and modernized it by making reforms to the judicial and economic system and promoted religious tolerance He introduced indirect taxation which increased the state’s revenue. Frederick took steps to control the price of grains and built government stores to help the poor in times of need. Frederick also propagated meritocracy by letting common men become judges and bureaucrats. In the judiciary, he banned the use of torture except for the punishment of flogging soldiers found guilty of desertion. A death penalty could only be signed by him, which he only did for murder. He was known for his compassion towards animals and opened Germany’s first veterinary school.

Gaius Marius and Julius Caesar were both what I would call ideal dictators.  The problem with both is that dictators die. Both GM and JC died and were replaced by utter bastards (Sulla) or anarchy (JC). Later "good emperors" took this extent a lot further.  Ditto Kings and Queens Louis XIV could be considered an ideal in many ways, but look what happened only a little after his death.  Even in the case of non-dictatorial executives- good men or great men are often succeeded by crooks or non-entities  For example: Truman was a good man, but he wasn't nearly as signifigant as FDR.

My vote goes to Kemal Ataturk, “The father of the Turks.” No one disputes he was a dictator, but consider two extremely unusual features of his rule from 1923 to 1938 : In an age when most dictators were expansionist he drew back Turkey’s borders and while most of his contemporaries aimed for totalitarianism he created a parliamentary republic, including an opposition party. From religion to women’s rights to education he was a fearless modernizer. He made Ankara first the provisional and later the juridical capital of the country. He defeated both the Greeks and the Western powers to proclaim Turkish independence. He abolished the Ottoman Empire, the Caliphate and proclaimed the birth of the Turkish Republic.  As the first president of the Turkish Republic, Atatürk set about building a modern and secular nation-state. He made primary education free and compulsory, changed Turkish from Arabic to Roman script, and built thousands of new schools all over the country. Turkish women received equal civil and political rights during Atatürk's presidency ahead of many Western countries. Also, he abolished the fez. His plan of Turkification—-to create a single, united and largely homogeneous nation—resulted in Turkey becoming 99% Islamic. This was the single biggest factor in preventing civil war at home and saving Turkey’s independence from covetous neighbors. He took “early retirement”, handing power over to a civilian successor while he played cards and gossiped with old cronies. At his death in 1938 the Turks proclaimed “Now there is no more shade.”

Yes ! Do not forget that Tyrant or Dictator are not necessarily bad things ! During the Antiquity , a Dictator ( mostly in Greek city states ) could be chosen to lead the people and save the country form incoming enemies or severe crisis . The word tyrant is now a negative word due to tyrannical rules which did not take into account people's opinions ( Hitler Stalin etc ) but it has not always been the case . Many “good” dictators such as Solon who lived in Athens seized power and ( pretty ironic ) proposed new laws and rights to the people of Athens , that would free the people of all their debts , bring back slaves , give more rights to women and men , and basically “saved” the city . Peisistratus and cleisthenes ( i am no historian correct me if I'm wrong ) went down that same path and changed Athenian political life and systems , and people supported them massively . They were in all pretty democratic and worked for the good of their city and citizens .

He will separate His sheep, the true believers, from those that don’t know Him or claimed to be Christian, when they were not, as confirmed in the following: Matthew 7: 21–23: Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven. Many will say to me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in thy name? and in thy name have cast out devils? and in thy name done many wonderful works? And then will I profess unto them, I never knew you: depart from me, ye that work iniquity. Matthew 25:31–46: When the Son of man shall come in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then shall he sit upon the throne of his glory: And before him shall be gathered all nations: and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats: And he shall set the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on the left. Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world: For I was an hungred, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me in: Naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye visited me: I was in prison, and ye came unto me. Then shall the righteous answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungred, and fed thee? or thirsty, and gave thee drink? When saw we thee a stranger, and took thee in? or naked, and clothed thee? Or when saw we thee sick, or in prison, and came unto thee? And the King shall answer and say unto them, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me. Then shall he say also unto them on the left hand, Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels: For I was an hungred, and ye gave me no meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me not in: naked, and ye clothed me not: sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not. Then shall they also answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungred, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thee? Then shall he answer them, saying, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me. And these shall go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life eternal.

Wanting to one-up Eyal Engelhardt Ari, because I'm a jerk like that, I'm going to go with Cincinnatus, named dictator of Rome twice (though for limited terms).  Both times, he resigned the dictatorship the very day the crises ended, this in spite of his relative poverty.  A Crassus, a Caesar, or (dare I say) even a Brutus would, at the very least, have served the term and used the position to their own advantage.  Cincinnatus has been revered for his love of his country so much that he surrendered his power when it wasn't necessary.

There seems to be a very comprhensive answer already here, but I would like to add something. I would elect Cyrus the Great as a benevolent dictator (which might be biased given my own name) who is often credited with the invention of human rights. And this is just the thing, the dictatorship, or monarchy, has been the principal form of government for most of history, so just its just a matter of probability there would have been many great dictators. The differance between dictatorships and democracies is that a president or prime minister can be bad or good, in terms of his influence on the country, but they generally can't be brilliant or catastrophic because of the limitations and checks and balances of a functional democracy. Along the same vein, a dictator could be brilliant, because all his intelligent policies wouldn't have to overcome opposition, but on the other end of the spectrum they could utterly destroy the country or start something basically universally negative like WWII. so the benefit of a democracy is that it's a healthy balance of the risks of poor governance.

King Sejong of Joseon Korea (1397 – 1450) was not a 'dictator' in the 20th century sense, but he was an absolute monarch. As such he had real power, and was like all such monarchs, in a position to abuse this power as many before him had done. Given this, his philosophy as king was highly unusual: "The purpose of a ruler is to serve the people. That is all."  Looking at his reign, we see that his accomplishments were all intended to help the ordinary people, who had little power of their own. The most celebrated of these achievements is the Korean alphabet Hangul. This was designed so that any subject could learn how to read in 24 hours. It's still used in Korea today, and is regarded with awe by linguists worldwide. In addition to this, he advanced printing so that knowledge could be spread as widely as possible, reformed the legal system to make life harder for corrupt officials, did research into medicine and published the results so that people could make their own remedies without having to pay for them, and so the list goes on. He blamed himself for most of the misfortunes that befell Korea during his reign, and this heavy responsibility was in part what drove his relentless quest for bettering the lives of the everyday folk. The historical accuracy of his acts is very hard to dispute, for the simple reason that the scholars who prepared the royal annals had a high degree of access to the king, and absolute protection in terms of what they wrote. No one was allowed to read the annals, in particular the king, for several generations afterwards. King Sejong himself was denied access to the annals concerning his father, King Taejong, for instance. The story of this unusual king is well worth reading about. There aren't a whole lot of English-language resources out there, but this is a pretty good one.

If you’re asking about modern era I would say no,definitely for me democracy is a higher rank requisite rather than a good but Tyranic (In the sense of all powered) leader although good. I am amazed that no one mentioned Comrade Josip Broz Tito! He is one of thee ideal modern Benevolent Dictators!  He led the Yugoslavian resistance against the Nazis. They were the only country in Europe who liberated themselves from the Nazis.Afterwards he created Yugoslavia which was one of the most ethnically diverse countries in Europe.He managed to stop the Bosnians, Croats, and other minorities from killing each otherHe was also a total badass, once even threatening to kill Stalin.He made the Yugoslavian army one of the best in Europe. I'll say Miguel Primo de Rivera. He was a spanish dictator, between 1923 and 1930, in the very politically convulsed period between the Restauration and Turnism, and the Second republic. He did very well. He made giant steps in the reduction of "Caciquismo" (The Caciques were very powerful men with huge networks, controlling the political issues of their regions). He also made a huge leap in infrastructure, modernizing the country, and was the first able to change the agricultural structure of the country, something very, very needed. He also started the Spanish petroleum company, CAMPSA, and the telephone company, Telefonica. He also put the first bases of the Seguridad Social, the welfare state.

Lee Kwan Yew of Singapore was in power from 1959 to 1990 officially, but then pretty much for another 24 years until he passed away in 2015, as various hand picked leaders ruled after him, including his son from 2004. While his position was prime minister, and he actually won elections, I think he qualifies as a benevolent dictator.  He found Singapore as an island with no natural resources and very little prospects, and turned it into a commercial and shipping hub with some of the highest standards of living in the world, strict rule of law, highly educated and skilled multiethnic work force producing a very high gdp per capita.  That said, he has also been criticized for draconian control of his population, through a slew of laws, even down to the banning of chewing gum. I suspect most Asian countries would take a leader like him any day.

After Kritoffer's answer it is hard to com up with another answer. But I 'd like to question the premise: is democracy better than dictatorship, what are the the downsides of democracy? For example think about the role of money in the US presidential campaign.  Does it diminish democracy?  In our Duch democracy there is so much compromise that one often wonders about the effect of some legal actions. The influence of multinationals on both democratic en dictarorial regimes, is it good or bad. And does it contribute to or distract from democracy? Historically seen democracy  is a fairly young. There have been very many absolute rulers and not all of them were bad for the population. Though one of the most notorious, Louis XIV, has left the French farmers with nothing to lose. Classic democratic Greek states are often small scale en limited to a certain class of citizens (male, landowning or taxpaying). Seventeenth century Netherlands are  an earlu modern example. Though organized on a nationwide level, one has to concede it is not a very large nation... And here also regents are the ones with the highest level of wealth.  As Kristoffer's answer shows nothing is intrinsically good or bad, it depends on how people wield democratic or dictatorial power.  I don't have the answers to the questions I raised here, just wanted to share them.

Napoleon Bonaparte was actually what you might call a "good dictator." He instituted many reforms in France, ended the French Revolution and the beheadings, and generally showed he could act in the best interests of France. Many of his tax-code reforms and education reforms still exist in France today. He got rid of Jewish ghettos and actually made Jews full citizens. He reformed quite a bit And had an impact all throughout Europe. The problems were, for starters, Napoleon was a conquerer. He tried to take over Europe. Europe didn't like that. Next he was actually one of the earliest modern dictators. He didn't come from the royalty that was Europe in the 18th and 19th centuries. He took power by force but the French loved him. It's crazy that, being the dictator that so many dictators respect and try to emulate, they failed to see how he actually helped France. Had he not tried to conquer the rest of Europe we may view him differently today.

Yes. Today. Prince Albert of Monaco. The people of Monaco pay no tax, they have free internet and cable. They have a pretty high standard of living. However, they do not have the right to vote. This makes Prince Albert a dictator, and to answer the question a good dictator. He is not alone in history (see other answers). I'm not certain on French history but i believe that King Louis XIV was a benevolent dictator, his son Louis XV was alright, but I can't find any articles on his grandson Louis XVI. Even if someone is a benevolent dictator, the principle of reversion to the mean predicts that the successor probably won't be.

Rome had a few. In emergencies they would elect a guy who became a dictator, intentionally, so that decisions could be made quickly. Usually war was the cause. The Romans didn't want to get wiped out, or suffer an empire-crippling injury. So they did what they had to do. The idea was that after the emergency was over the dictator would step down and normal government would step in. Obviously good dictators existed, otherwise the system would have been thrown out early on. Tyranny is when dictatorship turns evil. Today dictators and tyrants are often seen as the same thing, even though they most certainly are not. A dictator has complete power. A tyrant is a selfish dictator. There have been no good tyrants. There have been good dictators. Today a dictator would have a tough time becoming a dictator without being a tyrant. That's just the way the world is now, I believe.

Peisistratos  of Athens. He took over the city but ruled with the fiction he was still maintaining Solon's reforms. He even allowed himself to be summoned to court, although his accuser--tellingly--did not show up for the trial. His sons dispensed with the ruse, and ruled cruelly, resulting in the revolt that  invented democracy. I think you could include strong and popular rulers who most probably could have installed themselves as dictators, but chose not to. But Cincinnatus, Ataturk and George Washington are the only examples I can think of.

I'm surprised nobody else has nominated him yet, so I'll throw in Caesar Augustus to the mix. Absolute dictator, could be a brutal son-of-a-bitch if it suited him, still one of the best rulers in human history. On his deathbed, he boasted that he found Rome made of brick and left it made of marble, and he was justified in feeling proud of that. He established a line that didn't fall for nearly 2000 years, when World War I toppled the last Caesars (that'd be Tsar Nicholas and Kaiser Wilhelm), and he still lends his name to a month every year. Not bad at all.

From the 19th century, I nominate: Muhammad Ali of Egypt.   He gets my vote for: Being the Santa Claus of Dictators.Industrializing Egypt.Taking Egypt to its largest territorial extent.  Crushing Wahabbism in its infancy, if only you-know-whos hadn't helped its resuscitation.Made Arabic the official language of Egypt.Introduced Egypt's first newspapers.Sponsoring the education of the first generation of Egyptian elites.Restoring Egypt's pride of place in Middle-Eastern affairs.Shaking off the Ottoman bondage.Introduced cotton production into Egypt, driving up economic growth.Muhammad Ali is Egypt's greatest leader without a doubt, those before him and after pale in comparison.

Mustafa Kemal Atatürk  He was the first President of Turkey and led it through mandatory secular reform.  Abraham Lincoln led his country through federalizations and through executive power made the United States less divided and less racist (by abolishing slavery). Franklin Delano Roosevelt  He led some extremely controversial welfare and infrastructure programs and ultimately got America out of the depression as well as issuing a draft and ultimately defeating Nazi Germany, Imperial Japan, and Italy but not before serving 4 terms! Emperor Augustus. He may have started an autocracy but he certainly United Europe into prosperous age (Pax Romana).

Isn't the president of a Majority government, even though the majority was arrived at through democratic elections, in effect a dictator for the X years (in Canada, that would be 4) in power?  If you buy this, then I believe Pierre Elliot Trudeau fits the bill.  With a majority it was often an unapologetic "my way or the highway" but he dealt with wage and price controls (not a trivial matter), attempts at challenges to the country's sovereignty (from separatist Quebeq'ers as well as a somewhat hostile Western Canada thinking it could decide its own destiny based on oil resources)... and put Canada on the map in International relations.  Think about it: why would a country of then ~20 million people have global clout when it didn't invade anybody, scare anybody, or tell anyone else what to do?  Answer: because P.E.T. had that kind of charisma and influence.   And he didn't have anyone killed who disagreed with him.  One time he gave some protesters the middle finger... but if that is the biggest transgression one can fault a dictator on... there is harsher stuff on daytime TV. Truly a great man.  I don't know whether we will see his equal anytime soon.  I imagine JFK could have been in the league had he (a) lived long enough and (b) worked in a different system - the USA system splitting house and senate and mostly giving the president the right to veto, in effect makes the USA president (ignore nuclear codes for a moment) less powerful than the Canadian Prime Minister... because the Canadian Prime Minister while leading a majority govn't is accountable to *nobody* for four years.

During the period of the Roman Kingdom, and later in the Republic, a dictator was an appointed magistrate who was granted temporary emergency powers in order to resolve a crisis. Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus, was a retired Roman politician and military leader, who lived out his retirement quietly on his farm. Cincinnatus was appointed to the dictatorship in two separate instances in order to deal with national threats. Each time, he resolved the crises in under a month, returned power to the Senate, and returned to his farm to live out his retirement. Later, in the Roman Republic, when politicians were reluctant to cede power after their defined terms, Cincinnatus was often referenced as a symbol of officium, or duty, as a Roman who did his duty without ambition or expectation of personal reward.

First, we need to define "dictatorship" and then we must define "good. Then we can decide if human kind is capable of doing this. Dictators are a necessity in government. They rise when they are needed and they go away.   Dictatorships are good, but their long term consequences are bad. Greed, Power and Violence inevitably follow with a dictatorship. There will always be people against something.  A democracy, republic, socialism, communism are all equal. In an ideal setting they work. Add the human element and it is disaster, in fighting, chaos.

This Extra History episode concerning the Second Punic War goes into a bit of detail - both about Fabius Maximus and how dictatorship worked in the Roman Empire.

Yes, benevolent dictatorship is the best form of government. Turkey prospered under the reign of Kemal Pasha, not just econoically, but socio-culturally as well. If you take out atrocities against Jews, even Nazis were a very effective government. Within 19 years only, Hitler transformed Germany from a bankrupt nation to a global superpower. Even modern-day democracies have this practical provision. During war or other national emergencies, all powers are given in the hands of the President. This is to ensure quick decisions can be taken in spite of strong opposition. However, dictators are not benevolent by nature. Its a contrasting job description. So, its not applicable everywhere.

I've heard firsthand that the King of Bhutan, Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck , is very beloved and popular, and his people are dismayed with his efforts to convert the nation to a democracy.  Latest in the news:  Bhutan Celebrates Newborn Prince by Planting 108,000 Trees

Just a brief comment.  I think that, had Alexander the Great returned to Macedonia instead of dying at a relatively young age while still "in the field (swamp actually)", he might have become a benevolent dictator.  It is quite clear that he often was a benevolent military conqueror - provided none of the surrendering foes tried to betray his (often) generous surrender terms, in which case he would show no mercy to the betrayers.  He viewed himself as a uniter of cultures (particularly the Persian and Macedonian cultures).  He was willing to let local leaders and their cultures continue  . . . under the authority of his own representatives (Satraps).  He saw his mission as uniting the cultures of the world in a single (and fair) empire.  For his time, his attitude was pretty unique . . . for a conqueror.

Quite many. I’ll list just one: First Roman emperor Augustus. Anyone knowing Roman history knows that emperors generally were military dictators, not much like later monarchs at European kingdoms.. Position could be inherited but quite rarely son or close relative of previous emperor was good one. Ok, he rose to power after bloody civil wars, and “cleansings”. But after he was in supreme position he generally used his powers wisely, created stabile government, repaired state finances, put on end to mismanagement of provinces by senate approved governors, managed to return internal peace in most areas under Roman imperium, got army under his firm control and got general approval from people and senate.

The good dictator is a contradiction. The better he (or she) was or is, the less dictatorial. The more dictatorial, the worse he (or she) was or is.  The classic example is Pericles, charismatic leader of Athens for 32 years (461 to 429 BC). Was he a dictator? Thucydides said Athens was "in name a democracy but, in fact, governed by its first citizen". If he can be considered a dictator, then he comes as close to the ideal as is probably possible.

The Five Good Emperors, the ancient Roman imperial succession of Nerva (reigned ad 96–98), Trajan (98–117), Hadrian (117–138), Antoninus Pius (138–161), and Marcus Aurelius (161–180), who presided over the most majestic days of the Roman Empire. I'm only familiar with the last one, Marcus Aurelius, but he seems to have been the Platonic ideal of a Philosopher King.  I recommend his Meditations.

Although it's a little suspect to include older examples (since modern technology like surveillance and mass executions have made the bad things dictators do worse), a lot of 18th century monarchs could be considered. The "Enlightened Despots" as they were called (basically anyone known as "The Great," - Frederick in Prussia, Peter and Catherine in Russia, as well as Charles III in Spain, Joseph II and Maria Theresa in Austria) were certainly dictators in that they were all-powerful within their state, but did a lot to reform, modernize, and liberalize - as long as their power was unchallenged. You can make the same argument about Napoleon within France and at least some of the countries he conquered.

The Romans appointed Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus appointed dictator in 458BC when the state was fighting the Aequi and the Sabines. Fifteen days later, after defeating the enemy, he disbanded his army, resigned his dictatorship and returned to his farm. Some years later he performed a similar service for Rome by putting down a plot to overthrow the government. Once again, he returned to his farm.

Yes: Pinochet. When he got into power, the communists took control of Chile. They pretty much collapsed the country’a economy, terrorized citizens and foreigners. Pinochet imposed order, rebuilt the government, put a stop to communist infiltration, then imposed economic reforms, as advised by Chicago economists, then allowed the people to choose a different leader. Thanks to his economic reforms during his rule, Chile is now the greatest economy in South America.

There are many despots in history that have helped a country. Elizabeth the 1 of England ushered in a golden age for England in the late 16th century. During the age of enlightenment, "enlightened despots" reigned at times in Europe. Joseph the II of Austria made many enlightened reforms (which would be reverted upon his death). Catherine the Great also made many humanitarian reforms before the peasants caused her to revert the changes. Charles III of Spain, Charles I of Spain (Charles V of Holy Roman Empire), France under Louis XIV... The list goes on and on. Most of history men have been ruled by a "dictator" of some sort. One only has to look at successful countries to find successful rulers.

Depends not only on what you mean by good, but what you mean by dictator, The Roman "dictatorship" was not in the same class as modern, totalitarian dictators. and, of course, there were lots of +/- absolute monarchs all over the place. Many of them were good rulers by the standards of the day, and were popular: quite a few have been mentioned in other answers. I cannot think of a real world modern dictator, gaining power unconstitutionally, who could be called good. but there is a fictional one: try Vetinari in Ankh-Morpork.

A good dictator is better than a bad republic. Caesar Augustus was the first emperor of Rome, ending 500 years of "democracy". The senate had become an old boys club, favouring the aristocracy at the expense of the poor. Augustus issued reforms including state subsidised grain supplies, reforms that would have never have been achieved in the corrupt senate.  So the answer is, yes a dictator can be better than a republic however it is a very dangerous system because absolute power can so easily corrupt even the most noble of us.

Mr. Lee Kuan Yew or more fondly known as LKY was a dictator of Singapore. Today that tiny country is one of the few developed nations in Asia.  Lee's rule was criticised, particularly in the West, for curtailing civil liberties (public protests, media control) and bringing libel suits against political opponents. He argued that such disciplinary measures were necessary for political stability, which together with rule of law, were essential for economic progress Lee was no George Washington. He was a dictator but when compared to countries like India or Bangladesh which were democratic I would say I will love to live in Singapore under LKY.

There are two dictators who established themselves because they hated the corruption around them, not because they were corrupt. In recent times Flight Sergeant Jerry Rawlings of Ghana Who staged coups twice to expel corrupt governments and has worked tirelessly for democracy in his country. And (of course) Oliver Cromwell who cemented the primacy of parliament in the UK, even if he staged a coup against the parliament to do so. No angel, of course, but terribly effective. It suggests to me that some people - not very many, but some - can be trusted with interim dictatorship for short periods of time. But they have to be hugely principled individuals who think in terms of the greater good.

The whole thing clearly depends on your definition of a dictator. If you mean a person ruling a country for a longer period of time and having little or no risk of being kicked out of office by an election, then there are quite a few examples of “dictators” that left the country in a much better state than it was when they assumed power: 1/ Cardinal Richelieu left France in a much better state than when he assumef power 2/ Porfirio Diaz, Mexican president at the turn of the19th and 20th century 3/ President Lee of Singapore Now if you want to be controversial you could add Pinochet, a tyran that stole power from the democratically elected Allende bur that undisputably left Chile in a better state than the day he had Allende murdered!

Diocletian, Roman emperor in the late 3rd century AD. Tried to institute a system of shared rulership of the empire between four rulers to improve efficiency. Restored peace and order to the Roman world after almost a century of civil war and hardships. His system had the intention to try and create a peaceful procedure of succession of power. And he followed his own rules, stepping down from power to hand it on to the next generation.

Maybe a better question is, what form of governance is perfect? Or even 'good'? Answer: they all have faults in practice. Perhaps it might be better to find a way to reduce the faults further in forms of goverment seen as 'good'. The concept of a dictator appeals to some as it appears to be a way to remove the committee failure element; but betting on a dictator to be a good thing overall or even to stay 'good' is as hopeless as believing that any form of government is good for everyone.

Don Juan del Corral, the “dictator” of the state of Antioquia in Colombia, who first took power in 1810. Not only did he help to deliver the state from Spanish domination, but he also systematically liberated all the slaves in the region, at a time when no-one else in the country was doing this or regarded it as feasible. He used economic persuasion rather than force to persuade all the landowners to grant freedom to all their slaves. He was a dictator. He was a great, good man.
In modern times, Singapore leader Lee Kuan Yew is the canonical answer, although the fact that it's so hard to think of any other answer seems telling. Absolute power corrupts.

But in fact it was Xiaowendi who had done so much to make the country wealthy and strong enough. Wudi's expansion policy nearly destroyed Han. The problem with a dictatorship is that one person cannot rule a great land alone: a circle of people is required to carry out the dictator's directions.  The dictator also depends on this circle of people to provide information as to the state of the nation, the effect of directions etc. If these people are honest, and have the same goals as the dictator all might be well, as long as hubris does not cause the dictator, or any of the supporters, to misuse the power.  If they are not honest, and use their power and influence for their own benefit, then no matter how good and virtuous the dictator is, the country will suffer.

The vast majority of societies in history have been governed by some form of dictatorship. (Dictatorship is not the same as totalitarianism.)  I believe that in many cases, dictatorship has been "better" for most people than the alternative. Because in many situations, democracy is not a feasible and stable alternative. In some situations the only feasible alternative is anarchy, and dictatorship is often better than anarchy.

A "good dictator" reminds me of Plato's "Philosopher King" concept in his masterpiece "Republic". He is describing the ideal state, which is not run by democracy, but a Philosopher King. The best example of such a ruler in history is Marcus Aurelius, who was a Roman Emperor between 161-180. He was described by historians to have blameless character and temperate way of life, along with knowledge and application of philosophical doctrines: he wrote "Meditations", which describes the stoic philosophy of service and duty.

In the Roman republic they created the formal position of "dictator": someone who assumes supreme executive power for a limited period of time and should then quit. The classic example is Cincinnatus: Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus
